translated: Jātaka🔽The Collection of Birth Stories (Jātakas)
The Chapter on Gandhāri
The Birth Story of Susīma
“Your hair was black in the past,
Growing on your head in the right place;
Seeing it white today, Susīma,
It’s time to practice the Dhamma, to live the spiritual life.”

analyzed: mama iva deva palitam na tuyha
translated: “It’s me, your majesty, who’s gray, not you;
It’s my head, my highest part.
I spoke a lie, saying, ‘I’ll do good.’
Forgive me, best of kings, for this one offense.
You’re young and handsome, king,
like a peacock with its first feathers.
Rule the kingdom and watch me;
Don’t chase after what’s temporary, lord of the people.”
“I see you, a young girl,
with a beautiful body and a lovely waist,
like a black and blue bee flying around,
tempting men as you go.

original: Tamena passāmiparena nāriṁ,🔽Āsītikaṁ nāvutikaṁ va jaccā;
analyzed: passāmi parena nāri  āsītikam nāvutikam va jaccā
translated: But then I see that other woman,🔽over eighty or ninety years old,
walking with a stick,
moving like a cow’s hanging belly.
Thinking about that,
I lie alone in the middle of the bed;

original: ‘Ahampi evaṁ’ iti pekkhamāno,🔽Na gahe rame brahmacariyassa kālo.
analyzed: aham pi eva iti pekkhamāno  na gahe rame brahmacariyassa kālo
translated: Looking at it, thinking, ‘I too am like that,’

analyzed: rajju vālambanī ca isā  yā gehe vasataḥ
translated: I do not delight in the household life, the time for spiritual life is now.🔽This is the rope that binds🔽The pleasure of living in a home;
The wise cut it and go forth,
Without looking back, abandoning sensual pleasures.”
The Susāma Jātaka is the sixth.
